blog.name: what-a-waster
blog.title: Im stuck in my 2013 indie phase
blog.description: I’m kenny and I like music, fantasy books, and have like three chronic illnesses

body:
Hufflepuff House traits

Hufflepuffs are of course: just, loyal, fair, hardworking, determined, ethical, patient, and most importantly kind. Hufflepuffs aren’t ones to show off and do not attention seek. They do not care about status or material possessions. Hufflepuffs enjoy the simple pleasures in life, and understand the importance of love and friendship. In many ways they remind me of Hobbits. They aren’t afraid to rise to a challenge, and are good being selfless and using teamwork to get a job done. They can be very underrated at times and can use this to their advantage. Hufflepuffs are very accepting and tolerant, which is why they are often muggle born, and why Helga Hufflepuff agreed to “take the rest.” Hufflepuffs are often misfits who don’t necessarily fit in a certain box but when placed together become a family. Hufflepuffs are the value to being soft and kind, but the downside is they can be too forgiving or too accepting at times to where they end up getting hurt. Hufflepuffs are also loyal to a fault; if someone offends or hurts one of their own they can get overly hostile and worked up instead of taking some deep breathes and thinking first. Two examples are when they turn on Harry in the second book when they think he told the snake to attack Justin despite having no logical motive for it, and then again in the fourth year with the Cedric vs Harry in the triwizard tournament debacle. Hufflepuffs are very hard workers but this has the downside in that they can exhaust themselves or never stop to question authority on why they should be doing the work if that makes any sense. They are also very into fair play and abiding by the rules which can be a problem because sometimes in life you need to play dirty or break rules to get ahead. Overall though Hufflepuffs are usually unproblematic rays of sunshine like Penny Haywood which is why everybody loves them.

summary: So imagine:  A first grader with dissociative identity disorder is attending Hogwarts and called to be sorted. But the sorting...
body:
So imagine:

 A first grader with dissociative identity disorder is attending Hogwarts and called to be sorted. But the sorting hat doesn’t know where to put them, because all personalities are completely different but equally strong.

What now?

@welcometotheravenclawcommonroom

blog.name: what-a-waster
blog.title: Im stuck in my 2013 indie phase
blog.description: I’m kenny and I like music, fantasy books, and have like three chronic illnesses

body:
Gryffindor House traits

Gryffindors are obviously brave at heart and chivalrous but this can manifest in so many ways which one might not expect. A Gryffindor might be terrified of the idea of skydiving but have the courage to befriend the weird nerdy kid sitting alone at lunch and not care if people think it’s uncool or snicker. Gryffindors have a tendency to be super competitive (remember Oliver Wood) which can cause them to put themselves down or have too high expectations which can backfire. They refuse to quit and never say die which can be a good thing - if the golden trio were from any other house save Hufflepuff they would probably have given up on the horcrux search and gone home - but it can also be a bad thing such as when Hermione scheduled all those classes in her third year and became an underslept overstressed bitch. Gryffindors have a tendency to act first and ask questions later as opposed to the observational Ravenclaw or scheming Slytherin. Gryffindors also have a strong moral compass and realize that what’s right and wrong does not always match up with the laws of the land and societal norms, the prime example of course is the founding of Dumbledore’s Army. Gryffindors can also be reckless at times and break the rules just for the thrill of it such as with Lee, Fred, and George as well as the Maurauders, but this is not always the case (see Hermione and Percy). Gryffindors have big hearts and are more feelers than they are thinkers which is why they are often viewed as “the good guys” but it’s also why they can have drama and get their feelings hurt so easily. Gryffindors sometimes remind me of “football lads” in that they are fiercely loyal and look after each other and live life to the fullest. If you are a Gryffindor reading this and think well this or that doesn’t sound like me, it is important to remember that house traits are not black and white and two dimensional. Harry is the archetypal brave self sacrificing heroic Gryffindor, but Neville shows his bravery in the first year by standing up to his friends, and then in the fourth year at the Yule Ball. Neville is the only boy who looks forward to the Ball and the dancing because he isn’t afraid to appear soft or foolish, and he has a great time while Ron just grumpily sits with his arms crossed the whole time. McGonagall is another great example. She comes across as very straight laced and proper, but she is very just and fair, and deep down loves beating Slytherin in Quidditch, and seems to enjoy the dancing at the Yule Ball as well. She tries to not play favorites but deep down you know she loves Harry and her Gryffindor students to death and in the Battle of Hogwarts shows how much of a secret badass she really is at the core.


Gryffindor’s Interhouse Relations


Gryffindor’s most compatible house is probably Hufflepuff. They share a bit of overlap in the traits of fierce loyalty, strong beliefs in fairness and justice, and determination. This however does cause conflict in the Goblet of Fire with the whole Cedric vs Harry fiasco, as well as in the Chamber of Secrets when they think Harry set the snake on Justin. That aside though, the two houses get along rather well. They both are the two most accepting houses when it comes to muggle-borns, and a lot of Hufflepuffs supported Harry in the fifth book when nobody would believe him about Voldemort’s return. While the houses share the beliefs of justice and right vs wrong, Hufflepuffs are less likely to be reckless rule breakers willing to do whatever it takes than Gryffindors, and are more likely to be followers than leaders (in my opinion, I don’t have textual evidence to support this).


Gryffindors and Ravenclaws often can be opposites but that doesn’t mean they don’t get along. A matter of fact they often share secondary traits. Luna is very brave when you think about it, but it’s not her primary trait that you would associate her with, and Hermione is obviously highly intelligent and studious. Gryffindors tend to be more outgoing and wear their hearts on their sleeves while Ravenclaws are more inward and observational. Lockhart has a bold outgoing personality you would associate more with a Gryffindor but is actually a Ravenclaw because he is not brave in actuality. Gryffindors at times will clash with Ravenclaws because they are not big on taking their time to think things through or philosophize, and can get impatient or get frustrated when a Ravenclaw says something very unconventional and out of left field such as the dynamic between Hermione and Luna.


Gryffindors and Slytherins share more in common than they care to admit and therefore have the potential to be great friends as individuals. It’s a very complex relationship which the books sadly do not explore very well. Canonically when it comes to inter house relationships they are fierce rivals who do not get along in even the best of times and I think we shall leave it at that.

Gryffindors and Slytherins share more in common than they care to admit and therefore have the potential to be great friends as individuals. It’s a very complex relationship which the books sadly do not explore very well. Canonically when it comes to inter house relationships they are fierce rivals who do not get along in even the best of times and I think we shall leave it at that.

we are accepting all confessions at this time

summary: I’ve read the series before, multiple times actually, but I think I’m going to go through it again. This time, though, it’s...
caption:
I’ve read the series before, multiple times actually, but I think I’m going to go through it again. This time, though, it’s going to be very personal. I’m going to fall in love with these characters all over again, without worrying about the next shit thing Rowling says or does.

This time, I’m reading Harry Potter for me.
